title: Math-Viz
text:
PDE Visualization Framework
A comprehensive tool for solving and visualizing Partial Differential Equations with real-time 3D rendering.
Try it out: Live Web App
GitHub Repository: View on GitHub

Overview
Math-Viz provides an intuitive interface for exploring complex mathematical concepts through interactive 3D visualization.

Supported PDEs
PDE Overview
├── Heat Equation (Parabolic / Time-Dependent)
│   ├── Finite Domain (Bounded)
│   └── Infinite Domain (Unbounded)
│       ├── Fourier Transform
│       └── Heat Kernel (Fundamental Solution)
│
├── Laplace Equation (Elliptic / Steady-State)
│   ├── Cartesian (Rectangle)
│   │   ├── Dirichlet (Prescribed Value)
│   │   └── Neumann (Prescribed Derivative)
│   └── Polar (Disk)
│       ├── Dirichlet
│       └── Neumann
│
├── Poisson Equation (Elliptic / Steady-State)
│   ├── Dirichlet
│   └── Neumann
│
└── Wave Equation (Hyperbolic / Time-Dependent)
    ├── Finite Domain (Standing Waves)
    │   ├── 1D String (Separation of Variables)
    │   └── 2D Membrane (Sep. of Vars in Polar/Rect)
    │
    └── Infinite Domain (Traveling Waves)
        ├── 1D (D'Alembert's Formula)
        ├── 2D (Method of Descent / Poisson)
        └── 3D (Kirchhoff's Formula)



Features

Real-time 3D rendering
PDE solving capabilities
Interactive parameter adjustment
Export functionality

title: Mathematical Derivations
text:
The heat equation on a finite domain \([0, L]\) with Dirichlet boundary conditions:
\[\frac{\partial u}{\partial t} = \alpha \frac{\partial^2 u}{\partial x^2}, \quad u(0,t) = u(L,t) = 0\]
Solution via Separation of Variables:
Assume \(u(x,t) = X(x)T(t)\). This leads to:
\[\frac{1}{\alpha T}\frac{dT}{dt} = \frac{1}{X}\frac{d^2X}{dx^2} = -\lambda\]
where \(\lambda\) is the separation constant.
The spatial problem becomes: \[\frac{d^2X}{dx^2} + \lambda X = 0\]
with eigenvalues \(\lambda_n = \left(\frac{n\pi}{L}\right)^2\) and eigenfunctions \(X_n(x) = \sin\left(\frac{n\pi x}{L}\right)\).
The temporal problem gives: \[T_n(t) = e^{-\alpha \lambda_n t} = e^{-\alpha (n\pi/L)^2 t}\]
General Solution: \[u(x,t) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} B_n \sin\left(\frac{n\pi x}{L}\right) e^{-\alpha (n\pi/L)^2 t}\]
where coefficients \(B_n\) are determined by the initial condition: \[B_n = \frac{2}{L}\int_0^L u(x,0) \sin\left(\frac{n\pi x}{L}\right) dx\]

title: Mathematical Derivations
text:
The heat equation on a finite domain \([0, L]\) with Dirichlet boundary conditions:
\[\frac{\partial u}{\partial t} = \alpha \frac{\partial^2 u}{\partial x^2}, \quad u(0,t) = u(L,t) = 0\]
Solution via Separation of Variables:
Assume \(u(x,t) = X(x)T(t)\). This leads to:
\[\frac{1}{\alpha T}\frac{dT}{dt} = \frac{1}{X}\frac{d^2X}{dx^2} = -\lambda\]
where \(\lambda\) is the separation constant.
The spatial problem becomes: \[\frac{d^2X}{dx^2} + \lambda X = 0\]
with eigenvalues \(\lambda_n = \left(\frac{n\pi}{L}\right)^2\) and eigenfunctions \(X_n(x) = \sin\left(\frac{n\pi x}{L}\right)\).
The temporal problem gives: \[T_n(t) = e^{-\alpha \lambda_n t} = e^{-\alpha (n\pi/L)^2 t}\]
General Solution: \[u(x,t) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} B_n \sin\left(\frac{n\pi x}{L}\right) e^{-\alpha (n\pi/L)^2 t}\]
where coefficients \(B_n\) are determined by the initial condition: \[B_n = \frac{2}{L}\int_0^L u(x,0) \sin\left(\frac{n\pi x}{L}\right) dx\]

title: Mathematical Derivations
text:
Laplace Equation

Cartesian Coordinates (Rectangle)
The Laplace equation on a rectangle \([0,a] \times [0,b]\) with Dirichlet boundary conditions:
\[\nabla^2 u = \frac{\partial^2 u}{\partial x^2} + \frac{\partial^2 u}{\partial y^2} = 0\]
Separation of Variables:
Assume \(u(x,y) = X(x)Y(y)\):
\[\frac{1}{X}\frac{d^2X}{dx^2} + \frac{1}{Y}\frac{d^2Y}{dy^2} = 0\]
This gives: \[\frac{1}{X}\frac{d^2X}{dx^2} = -\lambda, \quad \frac{1}{Y}\frac{d^2Y}{dy^2} = \lambda\]

title: Mathematical Derivations
text:
Wave Equation

1D Wave Equation (Infinite Domain)
\[\frac{\partial^2 u}{\partial t^2} = c^2 \frac{\partial^2 u}{\partial x^2}\]
D’Alembert’s Solution:
The general solution can be written as: \[u(x,t) = f(x + ct) + g(x - ct)\]
where \(f\) and \(g\) are determined by initial conditions: - \(u(x,0) = \phi(x)\) (initial displacement) - \(\frac{\partial u}{\partial t}(x,0) = \psi(x)\) (initial velocity)
Explicit Formula: \[u(x,t) = \frac{\phi(x+ct) + \phi(x-ct)}{2} + \frac{1}{2c}\int_{x-ct}^{x+ct} \psi(\xi) d\xi\]

title: Mathematical Derivations
text:
Poisson Equation
\[\nabla^2 u = f(x,y)\]
The Green’s function approach provides the fundamental solution \(G(x,y; x_0, y_0)\) satisfying: \[\nabla^2 G = \delta(x-x_0, y-y_0)\]
For the 2D case: \[G(x,y; x_0, y_0) = -\frac{1}{2\pi} \ln\sqrt{(x-x_0)^2 + (y-y_0)^2}\]

More derivations coming soon…

title: Math-Viz: PDE Visualization Framework
text:
PDE Visualization Framework - A comprehensive tool for solving and visualizing Partial Differential Equations with real-time 3D rendering.

Quick Links

GitHub Repository
Live Web App



Current Features

Explicit Finite Difference Solver with stability control
Real-time 3D Visualization & analytical reference comparison
35+ Boundary Condition Functions
MP4 Export for animations
CLI + Web Interface
